title: English farmer sells vodka to the Russians
text:

Sun, Aug 2, 2015, 01:16 BST - UK Markets closed English farmer sells vodka to the Russians By Rebecca Burn-Callander | Telegraph – 5 hours ago 94.01 -1.20 
The Chase Distillery in Hereford has signed a deal to supply Russia's national drink back to the Motherland 
The Chase Distillery in Hereford, which distills vodka and gin, has signed a limited distribution deal with a Russian outfit to supply high-end bars and wine and spirit shops nationwide. 
Chase Vodka, which was the first start-up vodka and gin distillery in 200 years when it launched in 2008, has been attending bar shows in Russia for two years in an attempt to secure a deal. “I thought it would make an amazing story,” admitted James Chase, son of distillery founder William Chase, who also launched the Tyrell’s crisp brand. 
William Chase in his Herefordshire distillery 
Vodka is Russia’s national drink and its citizens drink 13.5 liters each year per capita. 
European vodkas have proved unpopular because Russian-made vodkas are typically low-cost, despite the former Russian President Dmitry Medvedev nearly doubling the minimum price of the spirit in an effort to combat excessive vodka consumption back in 2010. 
“There’s not much duty to pay over there,” said Mr Chase. “If you visit Russian supermarkets there are whole aisles dedicated to vodka.” 
Chase Vodka is also made from potatoes , which is popular in nearby Poland but unfamiliar in Russia, where wheat is the preferred raw material. 
The single estate vodka has beaten all odds to secure a listing in a anumber of Russian bars as well as VINO&Co’s wine and spirits shops across the country. 
According to Pavel Busygin, chairman of Russian Rusalca, which owns VINO&Co, “You might think that selling a vodka from UK to Russia is like selling sand in the desert, but Chase vodka has a very interesting concept - of a single estate vodka - which is quite different and attracts attention.” Chase Marmelade Vodka, distilled using the English preserve, has been a surprise hit. 
The Chase Distillery currently exports its spirits to 35 countries and Russia is likely to remain just a small percentage of its international revenue. 
“The most popular cocktails in Russia are still the B-52s and Lond Island Iced Teas,” said Mr Chase, who was speaking at the Eventbrite Summer School this week. “They are about 10 years behind the UK but bartenders are getting inspired by social media. 
“They see the cocktails that are big in places like London and New York, like the Negroni [one part gin, one part vermouth, and one part Campari (Milan: CPR.MI - news ) , garnished with orange peel] on Twitter (Xetra: A1W6XZ - news ) , Facebook (NasdaqGS: FB - news ) and Youtube and these are now becoming popular in the top Russian bars.” 
The main market for Chase Vodka in Russia is the British expat community. “There are lots of English people working there who want a taste of home,” claimed Mr Chase. 
The distillery will grow 60pc this year to hit £6.5m in turnover, he added. “We are making 10,000 bottles a week,” he said.
